summary: A letter from the New Mexico Attorney General's Office to the Southern District of New York, providing investigative materials related to Jeffrey Epstein's potential co-conspirators and offering continued cooperation. The letter references crimes occurring in New Mexico prior to 2008 and emphasizes the need to continue the investigation despite Epstein's death.

persons.name: Hector H. Balderas
persons.context: The Attorney General of New Mexico whose office is sending the letter and investigative materials to the Southern District of New York.

persons.name: Clara Moran
persons.role: Chief Deputy Attorney General of New Mexico
persons.context: The author of the letter, who signs off and offers direct contact for further cooperation.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The central figure in the criminal investigation; the letter discusses the investigation into his potential co-conspirators.

connections.description: Moran is the Chief Deputy Attorney General serving under Attorney General Balderas.
The letter references an investigation into Epstein's potential collaborators or co-conspirators.

events.title: Enactment of New Mexico human-trafficking statute
events.description: New Mexico enacted its human-trafficking statute, which is referenced as a legal cutoff for some conduct under investigation.

events.title: Epstein's death
events.description: The letter notes Epstein's death but argues it should not end the criminal inquiry into his collaborators.

events.title: Provision of investigative materials
events.description: The New Mexico AG's Office sends police reports, witness interviews, agency correspondence, and land lease documents related to Epstein to the SDNY.

keyFacts: The New Mexico Attorney General's Office is actively investigating potential co-conspirators of Jeffrey Epstein and has shared materials with the Southern District of New York.
The conduct under investigation in New Mexico occurred prior to 2008, the year the state enacted its human-trafficking statute.
The letter emphasizes that Epstein's death should not end the criminal inquiry and commits to continued cooperation.
The provided materials include police reports, recorded witness interviews, inter-agency correspondence, and documents related to Epstein's leasing of New Mexico public lands.
The office intends to work with the U.S. Attorney for the District of New Mexico to support any additional survivors of crimes in New Mexico.
